criteria: Consideration of Source Reliability and Appropriateness
descriptions: Student does not identify any sources of health information.
Student identifies only one source of health information.
Student identifies a few sources (2-3) but lacks detail on how to obtain information.
Student identifies several sources (3-4) and provides basic information on how to access them.
Student identifies multiple sources (4-5) with good detail on access and reliability.
Student comprehensively identifies a wide range of sources (5+) with excellent detail on access, reliability, and appropriateness.
Student provides no discussion on how to obtain information from sources.
Student provides minimal discussion with limited clarity on how to obtain information.
Student provides a basic discussion but may have gaps in understanding or clarity.
Student discusses methods of obtaining information, showing a reasonable understanding.
Student discusses methods effectively, demonstrating a strong understanding of how to approach different sources.
Student provides a comprehensive and insightful discussion of obtaining information, demonstrating an exceptional understanding of various methods and considerations.
Student does not consider the reliability or appropriateness of information sources.
Student mentions reliability or appropriateness briefly but lacks detail.
Student begins to consider reliability and appropriateness, but understanding is superficial.
Student considers reliability and appropriateness in some sources, demonstrating developing awareness.
Student effectively considers reliability and appropriateness across multiple sources.
Student critically evaluates the reliability and appropriateness of sources, demonstrating a sophisticated understanding.
